Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: SusChEM: Synthesis and Characterization of Disulfonated Poly(arylene ether sulfone 2,4,6-Trichloro-1,3,5-triazine) Hybrid Copolymers
Award.AbstractNarration: NON-TECHNICAL:<br/><br/>The objective of this CAREER project is to develop novel membrane materials for fuel cell applications and integrate this research into polymer education through appropriate courses and laboratory experiences. The research and education plan for this project will be achieved by: 1) Designing and preparing new fuel cell membranes for transport of electric charges; 2) Evaluating the properties and performance of the novel materials; 3) Modifying the materials to improve their properties; and 4) Merging polymer chemistry with general chemistry concepts by designing an "Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts" lecture and lab course for freshman students. The proposed research significantly enhances Fisk University's current and future research capabilities in polymer science through the introduction of this course that is deeply imbedded in the research objectives of this proposal, but simple enough to arouse student's interest and learning. Furthermore, the proposed two-semester introductory polymer course/inquiry-based lab experience, which is a student-selected alternative to traditional General Chemistry, will facilitate the enhancement of learning and research skills for undergraduate students. Introduction of authentic research beginning in the freshman year should also increase the retention of undergraduates (including underrepresented minorities) in STEM (science/technology/engineering/mathematics) and increase the pipeline of underrepresented talent for STEM careers.<br/><br/><br/>TECHNICAL:<br/><br/>The objective of the proposed research is to synthesize hybrid copolymers of disulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone)s (PAESs) by incorporating a post-modifiable unit, 2,4,6-trichloro-1,3,5-triazine (TT), into the polymer backbone. The significance of this approach is that the properties of the proton exchange membrane for fuel cells could be engineered for precisely tailored performance by tuning the microstructure of the copolymer backbone using varying and distinct structural/functional features. The disulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone- 2,4,6-Trichloro-1,3,5-triazine) (PAES-TT) hybrid copolymers will be prepared to form linear, high molecular-weight materials after optimizing the required synthetic steps. Subsequently, PAES-TT membranes will be prepared and characterized to evaluate their structure-property relationships and performance in proton-exchange-membrane fuel cell applications. <br/><br/>The educational component of this proposal is centered on developing an "Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts" lecture and lab course for freshman students as a means to incorporate student research experiences into the regular academic-year curriculum. Exposure of students to research, mentoring of students, broadening participation of underrepresented groups in science, and increasing the pipeline of underrepresented talent for STEM careers are other major components of the broader impacts of this project.

Performance_Institution.Name: Florida Agricultural Mechanical University
Performance_Institution.StreetAddress: 1601 S Martin Luther King Jr Blvd.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research and educational objectives of this project were to 1) Develop a series of novel and tailorable polymers suitable for fuel cell membranes and 2) Design an Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts lecture and lab courses that integrate authentic polymer chemistry research into the General Chemistry curriculum.  The project began at Fisk University in Nashville, TN and was completed at Florida A & M University (FAMU).

At Fisk, over sixty minority students were trained throughout the research and educational activities over four years.  The research efforts resulted in multiple undergraduate and graduate researchers? acceptance and enrollment in PhD programs at Vanderbilt University, Virginia Tech, Louisiana State University, and Colorado State University.  Additionally, one publication in 2019 to Polymer and two other manuscripts submitted in 2022 to the Journal of Polymer Research and Journal of Applied Polymer Science.  Numerous conference proceedings from Fisk Research Symposium, NOBCChE, SERMACS, and American Chemical Society Meeting also resulted from this work.  The Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts lecture and lab courses, trained fifty plus students to operate advanced analytical instruments, analyze data, and design research projects related to everyday issues. Soft skills such as teamwork, critical thinking, and communication were also developed as students had to present their projects as class reports or at the Fisk Research Symposium. Projects designed in this course won top awards at the Fisk Research Symposium and TSLAMP conference.

At FAMU, two graduate students and one undergraduate student were trained through the research.  All students applied to graduate programs with one student beginning the biomedical engineering program at Virginia Tech in Fall 2021.  The educational activities of this project were adjusted when the project was transferred to FAMU. Instead of a lecture and lab series, polymer concepts were incorporated into the Advanced Organic Chemistry lecture undergraduate and graduate courses where at least two-thirds of the course focused on learning basic polymer concepts and characterization tools needed to prepare polymers for various applications. The end of the course charged students with using their polymer knowledge to design an experiment and write a proposal on polymers for water filtration, drug delivery, and fuel cells. Students worked in teams and presented their proposed work in both written and oral formats.   

Overall, the intellectual merits found that incorporation of monomers with reactive functional groups yielded membranes with poor mechanical properties while the fabrication of composite membranes that utilized phosphonated and sulfonated additives increased the performance of unmodified polymer. Favorable feedback from students were received about the Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts lecture and lab courses through internal and external along pre- and post-evaluations as most students found it challenging but appreciated the drive to connect the course concepts to real life issues. Ultimately the broaden impacts to increase the number of minority students at historically black institutions, who pursue research and STEM careers post-graduation and who evidence deep learning of basic concepts by applying them in novel situations were also achieved as many of the minority researchers engaged in this project have transitioned to PhD programs nationally.

 


Last Modified: 03/17/2022
Modified by: Natalie Y Arnett

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research and educational objectives of this project were to 1) Develop a series of novel and tailorable polymers suitable for fuel cell membranes and 2) Design an Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts lecture and lab courses that integrate authentic polymer chemistry research into the General Chemistry curriculum. The project began at Fisk University in Nashville, TN and was completed at Florida A & M University (FAMU). At Fisk, over sixty minority students were trained throughout the research and educational activities over four years. The research efforts resulted in multiple undergraduate and graduate researchers? acceptance and enrollment in PhD programs at Vanderbilt University, Virginia Tech, Louisiana State University, and Colorado State University. Additionally, one publication in 2019 to Polymer and two other manuscripts submitted in 2022 to the Journal of Polymer Research and Journal of Applied Polymer Science. Numerous conference proceedings from Fisk Research Symposium, NOBCChE, SERMACS, and American Chemical Society Meeting also resulted from this work. The Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts lecture and lab courses, trained fifty plus students to operate advanced analytical instruments, analyze data, and design research projects related to everyday issues. Soft skills such as teamwork, critical thinking, and communication were also developed as students had to present their projects as class reports or at the Fisk Research Symposium. Projects designed in this course won top awards at the Fisk Research Symposium and TSLAMP conference. At FAMU, two graduate students and one undergraduate student were trained through the research. All students applied to graduate programs with one student beginning the biomedical engineering program at Virginia Tech in Fall 2021. The educational activities of this project were adjusted when the project was transferred to FAMU. Instead of a lecture and lab series, polymer concepts were incorporated into the Advanced Organic Chemistry lecture undergraduate and graduate courses where at least two-thirds of the course focused on learning basic polymer concepts and characterization tools needed to prepare polymers for various applications. The end of the course charged students with using their polymer knowledge to design an experiment and write a proposal on polymers for water filtration, drug delivery, and fuel cells. Students worked in teams and presented their proposed work in both written and oral formats. Overall, the intellectual merits found that incorporation of monomers with reactive functional groups yielded membranes with poor mechanical properties while the fabrication of composite membranes that utilized phosphonated and sulfonated additives increased the performance of unmodified polymer. Favorable feedback from students were received about the Introduction to Polymer Chemistry: General Chemistry Concepts lecture and lab courses through internal and external along pre- and post-evaluations as most students found it challenging but appreciated the drive to connect the course concepts to real life issues. Ultimately the broaden impacts to increase the number of minority students at historically black institutions, who pursue research and STEM careers post-graduation and who evidence deep learning of basic concepts by applying them in novel situations were also achieved as many of the minority researchers engaged in this project have transitioned to PhD programs nationally.
